awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Preserving Privacy in the Use of Digital Currencies
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this EAGER project will be on the $3 trillion digital asset market. The project will consider whether new technologies can afford a consumer or business greater privacy in a digital currency payment in order to support the development of this rapidly growing market. The proosed work includes core software and infrastructure development that balances users’ preferences with regulatory requirements and strives to build a more efficient digital payment system. Through collaborative, multi-disciplinary technical research, the project will evaluate digital currency design choices under different assumptions and requirements, evaluate tradeoffs, and ultimately learn how digital currency systems can be designed to best advance privacy, user agency, innovation, and financial equity. The latter objective includes improved financial access for low income and other vulnerable populations, an important global challenge. Because the project intends to release research papers and code, this work may catalyze others’ efforts in the public and private sectors to build on our research. This work will thereby provide critical insight for central bankers, policymakers, and the financial services industry as they contemplate the design and potential issuance of digital assets for use in the economy.

This EAGER project proposes to preserve privacy in the use of a central bank digital currency (CBDC). The project will estimate the speed and storage implications of cryptographic approaches including pseudonymization, zero-knowledge proofs, and private information retrieval, to limit the information that each provider sees about participants in a transaction while complying with regulation. The test platform will be on OpenCBDC, a payments model in which the central transaction processor authenticates and stores unspent funds (called unspent transaction outputs, or UTXO) as cryptographic hashes. The project will address one of the most latency-intensive parts of a privacy-preserving design, namely range proof verification, using two architectures. One is batch proof creation, in which the prover must show that multiple values fall below a specified range. The second is batch proof verification, in which the verifier considers whether multiple proofs are all valid. This project presents high risks because it is unknown whether this technology can safeguard privacy adequately, at scale, and in a manner that is sensitive to legal, regulatory, and political concerns. It presents potentially high returns because demonstrating that well designed digital money can safeguard privacy at a level similar to cash could influence the design of payments instruments for decades.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Preserving Privacy in the Use of Digital Currencies

This research explored technology to preserve privacy when using central bank digital currency (CBDC) or privately issued digital assets as a payments instrument. The volume of non-cash payments continues to grow rapidly in the United States and abroad, even for small-value transactions. While cash transactions generally do not create data trails and can be anonymous, digital transactions generate volumes of data that others can monitor, track, or store for commercial targeting or government monitoring. Privacy considerations are increasingly important among users of mobile- and app-based payments and digital assets such as stablecoins, cryptocurrency, or CBDC and must be considered in designing new forms of digital money. 


This EAGER grant supported our ongoing privacy research and made it more widely available to inform public dialogue on privacy in the use of digital currency. Data leaks, surveillance, and other privacy failures can have severe consequences for users, particularly the most vulnerable, by increasing the risk of exploitation, often without their knowledge or consent. Moreover, achieving other public policy goals, such as preventing fraud, money laundering, or terrorism financing, currently requires financial institutions to gather information on customers and their sources of funds. Finding practical solutions may unlock the positive potential of digitizing public money. For example, the data trails a CBDC generates could improve a financial service provider’s understanding of a user’s financial profile and potentially her creditworthiness. Finding the appropriate balance between the risks and opportunities for such data usage may help build public trust in using digital assets such as CBDC by safeguarding sensitive data and users’ privacy. 


The EAGER grant supported three projects related to privacy.


  1. Privacy-preserving audits: We completed our project’s first phase to enable a central bank to audit the digital currency supply in circulation without accessing information on specific users and their transactions. The technology runs as an extension of OpenCBDC, the open-source transaction processor jointly developed by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston and MIT DCI for experimentation and research. We have published our research and technology as a working paper on our website, enabling researchers at central banks, universities, and other institutions to use this technology in their research.

  1. The EAGER grant enabled us to finish work with a major central bank’s staff to study the possible application of privacy-enhancing technologies (PETs) to a potential CBDC. We investigated the technical challenges, trade-offs, opportunities, and risks of using emerging PETs to support privacy while ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements regarding anti-money laundering and combating the financing of terrorism. We found that cryptographic techniques like pseudonymization, zero-knowledge proofs, and multiparty functionalities may be increasingly feasible for possible deployment. These technologies have been deployed in other contexts, showing their increasing maturity and practicality. A CBDC might, in the fullness of time and as the technology matures, make use of these emerging PETs. PETs might help enhance user privacy and thereby support trust and confidence in a CBDC. In particular, PETs could, in theory, help financial institutions discharge responsibilities around customer due diligence requirements (“know your customer” rules), validate transactions, and comply with core AML/CFT regulations while minimizing the sharing of personal data. As such, PETs might help to align both the privacy objectives and the compliance requirements for a CBDC, presenting opportunities to use these technologies to provide stronger privacy protection than what exists today. We will publish our joint research paper later this year on three specific PETs and how they could minimize the sharing of personal data between payment intermediaries and give users greater control over their data.

  1. Finally, the EAGER grant supported research on scalable privacy-preserving payments in a centralized setting, including CBDCs. Though designs for privacy-preserving digital cash and payments have a rich history, CBDCs introduce new requirements such as auditability to assure users that the currency in circulation matches what is expected. Even the possibility of counterfeiting might weaken trust in the currency.  We focused on two designs that safeguard payment details between counterparties, Chaumian e-cash and Merkle tree-based systems, and differences in their security assumptions and scalability. Our work highlighted scalability limitations in Merkle tree-based privacy systems in a large network such as a CBDC. We proposed a sharded Merkle tree design to improve scalability while maintaining strong privacy. However, conventional sharding methods pose privacy risks, so we introduced a new “tree of sharded trees” design that preserves privacy with a modest increase in latency. We described, implemented, and evaluated all three designs, finding that unmodified Merkle tree designs experience resource-contention-induced scalability bottlenecks. In contrast, our new design achieves throughput that is less than an order of magnitude away from e-cash, despite providing auditability. The grant supported a graduate student’s thesis advisor, which resulted in publishing the student’s master’s thesis.
